{{More citations needed|date=January 2018}} {{Update|date=February 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}}
{{Infobox comedian | name = Josie Long | image = Josie Long 2013.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Long at Long Division Festival in June 2013 | pseudonym = | birth_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1982|4|17}} | birth_place = [[Sidcup]], England | death_date = | death_place = | medium = Stand-up, television, radio, film | nationality = British | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Oxford]] | active = 1990s-present | genre = | subject = <!-- | influences = [[Lee and Herring]], [[The Mary Whitehouse Experience]], [[Monty Python]]<ref>{{citation | place = IE | url = http://www.irishtimes.com/1.2085652 | date = 6 February 2015 | title = Josie Long: ‘Everyone expects me to talk about politics’ | work = The Irish Times| accessdate = 5 April 2015}}</ref> --> | spouse = | domesticpartner = [[Jonny Donahoe]] | children = | notable_work = | website = {{url|josielong.com}} }}
'''Josie Long''' (born 17 April 1982) is a British comedian.<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/profile/josielong |title=Josie Long |work=The Guardian |date=21 October 2014 |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> She started performing as a stand-up at the age of 14 and won the BBC New Comedy Awards at 17. In 2006, she won the [[If.comeddies]] Best Newcomer award at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] for her show ''Kindness and Exuberance''. She has been nominated for the Edinburgh Comedy Award for Best Show three times. In 2012, Long and director Doug King produced two short comedy films in Glasgow called ''Let's Go Swimming'' and ''Romance and Adventure'', which were nominated for a BAFTA Scotland New Talent Award.
==Early life and education== Long was born in [[Sidcup]] and spent her early life in [[Orpington]], [[London|Kent]],<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/my-secret-life-josie-long-comedian-28-2037464.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Charlotte | last=Philby | title=My Secret Life: Josie Long, comedian, 28 | date=31 July 2010}}</ref> where she attended [[Newstead Wood School for Girls]] and was in Swift House. She began performing stand-up comedy at 14, winning the [[BBC New Comedy Awards]] at the age of 17. Long attended Michael Knighton's comedy course in Beckenham, Kent. At 18 she gave up stand-up whilst attending [[Lady Margaret Hall]], [[University of Oxford]], though she ran experimental comedy clubs while at university, and graduated with a degree in English.<ref name="AutoB3-1"/>
==Career== After graduating Long returned to live stand-up, supporting [[Stewart Lee]] on his spring 2005 tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://daamanagement.co.uk/clients_detail.asp?id=22 |title=DAA Management Ltd – CLIENTS – JOSIE LONG |publisher=Daamanagement.co.uk |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref>
She contributed [[Sketch comedy|sketches]] and [[One-line joke|one-liners]] to [[BBC Radio One]]'s 2004/05 comedy show, ''The Milk Run''<ref name="theguardian1"/> with [[Andrew O'Neill]]. One edition of the show was entirely given over to a script she co-wrote with her friend Dan Harkin, entitled ''The Adventures Of [[Marco Polo]]''.
In 2005 she began publishing a fanzine, ''Drawing Moustaches in Magazines Monthly Magazine (Bi-Monthly)'', which is distributed for free, and has featured contributions from [[Robin Ince]], [[Kevin Eldon]] and [[Stewart Lee]], as well as [[Danielle Ward]] and [[Isy Suttie]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.josielong.com/drawing_moustaches.php |title=Official website of Josie Long, Comedian! |publisher=Josie Long.Com |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref>
She appeared in the show ''An Audience With Dan Nightingale & Josie Long'' with [[Manchester|Mancunian]] comic Dan Nightingale, at the Café Royal, at the 2005 [[Edinburgh Fringe]]. In 2006 she won the [[If.comeddies|If.comedies]] Best Newcomer award at the Fringe for her show ''Kindness and Exuberance''. In her 2007/2008 tour ''Trying is Good'' her act often involved drawing a sea scene on her arms and stomach. Long has a love of [[applique]] and the [[V&A]] Museum, and live [[Boggle]] contests sometimes form a part of her performances.
[[File:Josie Long (cropped).jpg|thumb|Long in 2010]] As of 2014 she has performed seven solo shows at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and performed five subsequent UK tours in springs 2007, 2008 and 2009, Autumn 2010 and spring 2012. She has appeared at the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]] (2007–10), the [[Adelaide Fringe Festival]] (2008), the [[New Zealand Comedy Festival]] (2008, 2010) and the Montreal [[Just For Laughs]] Festival (2008). Her show, ''Trying is Good'' was nominated for the Barry Award in Melbourne 2008. In 2009 she toured her show ''All of the Planet's Wonders'', playing 14 dates during February and March. Her radio series based on the show, ''Josie Long: All of the Planet's Wonders'' was broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] in early 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00hkrbn |title=BBC Radio 4 Extra – Josie Long: All of the Planet's Wonders |publisher=BBC |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref>
Long has been nominated for the Edinburgh Comedy Award for Best Show three times, with her 2010 show, ''Be Honourable!'', 2011's ''The Future Is Another Place'' and 2012's ''Romance & Adventure''.<ref>{{cite news |title=List of Comedy Awards Nominees & Winners |date=31 October 2014 |first=Comedy |last=Awards |url=http://www.comedyawards.co.uk/comedyshow.asp |work=Comedy Awards |accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Josie Long performing at Lost Treasures of the Black Heart in London on the 11th of September 2013.JPG|thumb|Josie Long performing at Lost Treasures of the Black Heart in September 2013]]
Along with fellow comics [[Hils Barker]], Steve Hall and [[James Sherwood (comedian)|James Sherwood]], she founded the ''All-Singing, All-Dancing Competitive News Bonanza'', a live topical panel show that ran at the [[Red Lion pub]] in [[Soho]] in 2004/05, and at the Arts Theatre Club in Soho in 2006. In 2006 she also launched her own monthly comedy clubs, the ''Sunday Night Adventure Club'', at the ABC Café in [[Crystal Palace, London|Crystal Palace]], London (later at the Black Sheep pub), and ''The OK Club'' at the Boogaloo pub in [[Highgate]], [[North London]]. She currently runs and hosts "The Lost Treasures of the Black Heart" comedy club in [[Camden Town]], which is recorded and made available as a podcast.
Long has written for the [[Channel 4]] teen comedy-drama series ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]''. She has also appeared in an online [[webisode]] and episodes five and ten of the second series of the show, in which she plays a college careers adviser, and appeared again in episode 5 of the third series, reprising that role, this time, however, in another career. She makes a return appearance in series 6 as the college guidance counselor in episode 1.
She has also been involved in [[BBC Switch]], on a weekly mini-feature called ''Josie Long's Confuse the Teacher Feature'', where a word is read out by Long for young people listening to the show to include in their homework, which was formed after her suggestion of the idea during an interview on the show with [[Annie Mac]].
She also appeared regularly in [[Robin Ince]]'s [[podcast]] ''Show & Tell'', now called ''Robin and Josie's Utter Shambles'', co-hosted the [[Resonance FM]] show ''I, DJ'' with Danielle Ward and [[Isy Suttie]], and guested on ''[[Answer Me This!]]'' podcast. She has also DJed at the London [[indiepop]] club night Scared To Dance.<ref name="AutoB3-2"/> She appeared on the ''[[Jon Richardson (entertainer)|Jon Richardson Show]]'' on 27 July 2008 and again on 15 February 2009. On 9 October 2008 she appeared on ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' in the second programme of the 22nd series. On 19 January 2009 she appeared on the radio panel game ''[[Just a Minute]]''.<ref name="AutoB3-3"/> She appeared in Australian improvised-comedy show ''[[Thank God You're Here]]'' twice, the first of which aired on 6 May 2009. On 5 July 2009 she appeared on [[Sunday Night Show]] on [[Absolute Radio]] with [[Iain Lee]]. On 14 and 28 July 2009 she appeared on [[Charlie Brooker]]'s [[Channel 4]] show ''[[You Have Been Watching]]''.
On 21 and 23 August 2009 Long performed at the [[Green Man Festival]]. On 15 November 2009, Long was the guest on the [[Dave Gorman]] radio show on [[Absolute Radio]] and the subsequent podcast of the show, before making her second appearance with [[Iain Lee]], this time on Iain Lee's ''2 Hour Long Late Night Radio Show'', on the same station eight days later. She occasionally wrote for [[Alan Moore]]'s underground magazine ''[[Dodgem Logic]]''.
On 15 January 2010 she was a contestant on [[Channel 4]]'s panel show ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]''. On 18 March 2010 she appeared on the [[BBC Two]] comedy quiz TV programme show ''[[The Bubble (UK TV series)|The Bubble]]'', during which she notably wore a garment displaying [[Aneurin Bevan|Nye Bevan]] related witticisms. She wrote and performed three short plays as part of [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Afternoon Play]]'' series, including one about [[apostrophe]]s.
Since 2010, Long has been involved with the anti–tax-avoidance activist group [[UK Uncut]], and in 2011 co-founded [[The Arts Emergency Service]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/apr/19/josie-long-comedian-student-charity|title=Stand-up to help students with new charity|author=Mary O'Hara|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=19 April 2011}}</ref> a charity helping young people in education. She has on occasion promoted these groups through her stand-up and has also performed stand-up at protests and occupations, including the [[2011 Hetherington House Occupation]].
Long presented a Saturday morning radio show with [[Andrew Collins (broadcaster)|Andrew Collins]] on [[BBC 6 Music]]<ref name="AutoB3-5"/> and runs a monthly comedy club at The Black Heart in Camden Town, recordings of which are used for her new podcast ''The Lost Treasures of the Black Heart''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.losttreasurespodcast.com/ |title=The Lost Treasures of the Black Heart, a podcast by Josie Long & Friends |publisher=Losttreasurespodcast.Com |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> Since 2013 she has been the presenter on BBC Radio 4's ''Short Cuts'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01mk3f8|title=Shortcuts}}</ref> which was nominated for Best Speech Programme at the Radio Academy Awards in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radioacademyawards.org/winners/index.cfm?winners_year=2014&winners_award_group_id=1&winners_award_category_id=1|title=The Radio Academy Awards|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216191842/http://www.radioacademyawards.org/winners/index.cfm?winners_year=2014&winners_award_group_id=1&winners_award_category_id=1|archivedate=16 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2012, Long toured the UK with [[Grace Petrie]], Tom Parry and the activism group [[UK Uncut]] to protest against public-sector government funding cuts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gigglebeats.co.uk/2012/01/im-annoyed-that-the-world-is-not-how-id-like-it-and-i-wish-i-could-change-it-an-interview-with-josie-long/|title=Interview: Josie Long|newspaper=Giggle Beats|access-date=17 January 2017}}</ref> Long and director Doug King also produced two short comedy films in Glasgow called ''Let's Go Swimming'' and ''Romance and Adventure'', which were nominated for a BAFTA Scotland New Talent Award. The pair toured independent cinemas across the UK during Autumn 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Josie Long in comedy short film tour |date=6 September 2013 |first=Andrew |last=Dipper |url=http://www.gigglebeats.co.uk/2013/09/josie-long-in-comedy-short-film-tour/ |work=Giggle Beats |accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref>
Long has been a ''[[Doctor Who]]'' fan since she was a child<ref>{{cite web|last1=Berry|first1=Steve|title=Behind the Sofa: Celebrity Memories of Doctor Who|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=usB-kPT4OOAC&pg=PT15&lpg=PT15&dq=%22doctor+who%22%22josie+long%22&source=bl&ots=COUXJn9QYX&sig=MOPxC9IpR0482C-bXNDnZQWi238&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CF4Q6AEwDWoVChMI9IzR9ZLqxwIVR0AaCh3tiwGh#v=onepage&q=%22doctor%20who%22%22josie%20long%22&f=false|publisher=Orion Books|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref> and she is interviewed for the special features of several classic series DVD releases, including ''[[Nightmare of Eden]]'' and ''[[Dragonfire (Doctor Who)|Dragonfire]]''.
In August 2015, Long endorsed [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s [[Jeremy Corbyn Labour Party leadership campaign, 2015|campaign]] in the [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2015|Labour Party leadership election]].{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)-->
On 28 May 2018, Long gave birth to a daughter (https://twitter.com/JonnyDonahoe/status/1001510136949739521?s=09)
== Live credits == * 2014 ''Cara Josephine'' (Stand-up show at Edinburgh Fringe, National Tour) * 2012 ''Romance and Adventure'' (Stand-up show at Edinburgh Fringe, Melbourne International Comedy Festival 2013, New Zealand International Comedy Festival 2013 & UK tour) * 2011 ''The Future is Another Place'' (Stand Up Show at the Edinburgh fringe, Uk tour) * 2011 ''MaxFunCon'' (Stand up show at conference in Lake Arrowhead, California, USA) * 2010 ''Be Honourable!'' (Stand Up Show at the Edinburgh Fringe, New Zealand and Melbourne Comedy Festivals, Uk tour.) * 2009 ''Darwin's Birthday Spectacular'' with Robin Ince * 2009 ''All of the Planet's Wonders (Shown in Detail)'' (Edinburgh fringe, UK and Australian Tour) * 2008 ''Trying is Good'' (Edinburgh fringe, UK, NZ, Montreal and Australian Tour. UCB Los Angeles) * 2006 ''Kindness and Exuberance'' (Edinburgh fringe, UK and Australian Tour. UCB New York)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.josielong.com/shows.php |title=Official website of Josie Long, Comedian! |publisher=Josie Long.Com |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref>
== Radio credits == * 2015 ''Short Cuts'' on BBC Radio 4<ref name="Short Cuts">{{cite web|title=Short Cuts|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0403rhf|work=BBC Radio 4|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> * 2014 ''Short Cuts'' on BBC Radio 4<ref name="Short Cuts"/> * 2013 ''Come the Revolution'' on BBC Radio Wales<ref name="Come the Revolution">{{cite web|title=Come the Revolution|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0380qzv/broadcasts/2014/03|work=BBC Radio Wales|publisher=BBC|accessdate=7 March 2014}}</ref> * 2013 ''Short Cuts'' on BBC Radio 4<ref name="Short Cuts 2">{{cite web|title=Short Cuts|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01mk3f8/episodes/guide|work=BBC Radio 4|publisher=BBC|accessdate=7 March 2014}}</ref> * 2011 Andrew Collins and Josie Long on BBC 6 Music<ref name="AutoB3-5"/> * 2010 ''So Wrong, It's Right'' hosted by Charlie Brooker on BBC Radio 4 * 2010 ''The Adult Hour'' on TalkSport hosted by Ian Collins * 2009 ''All the Planet's Wonders'' on BBC Radio 4<ref name="AutoB3-6"/>
== Television credits == *2016 ''Dara O'Briain's Go 8-Bit'' , Season 1 Episode 5, Dave *2015 ''Celebrity Fifteen to One'', Winner, Channel 4<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/episode/cvbkmx/celebrity-fifteen-to-one--series-1---episode-1 |title=Celebrity Fifteen to One | Series 1-Episode 1 |work=Radio Times |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> * 2014 ''8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown'', Channel 4 * 2014 ''Fifteen to One'', Channel 4 * 2013 ''8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown'', Channel 4 * 2013 ''Was It Something I Said?'', Channel 4<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/was-it-something-i-said/on-demand/56640-004 |title=Was It Something I Said? – Episode 7 – All 4 |publisher=Channel 4 |accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> * 2013 ''The Matt Lucas Awards'', BBC1 * 2010 ''The Bubble'', BBC2 * 2009 ''Skins'', Channel 4, as Josie, the group's careers advisor in series 2 and then English teacher in series 3 * 2009 ''Maeve Higgins' Fancy Vittles'', RTÉ2 (Ireland), as [[Maeve Higgins]]'s English friend
== References ==
